bibl.title: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Laura Armistead Carter, May 9, 1928

div1.p: Frost believes that the entire History of Yellow Fever should be published at one time as each section builds on the previous section.

div1.head: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Laura Armistead Carter, May 9, 1928
div1.opener:
Book
Frost
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
615 NORTH WOLFE STREET
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
BALTIMORE, MD.
May 9, 1928.
Miss Laura Carter,
The Westmoreland Apts.,
2122 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Miss Laura:
div1.p:
I have been intending each day and each night
to write to you in reply to your letter of last week
but for one reason or another have not got around to
it until now, when I am on a point of leaving for Iowa,
Nebraska and Cincinnati on a ten-day trip.

I have been thinking over your question about the
possible publication of Part 2, Section III, of your
Father's manuscript in advance of the full publication.
However, I cannot see that this would really serve any
useful purpose. For one thing, the history is so written
that the argument in each section depends to a consid-
erable extent on what has been presented in previous
sections and expecially as to the African origin of yel-
low fever the evidence for it is to a large extent based
on the previous exclusion of America.

When I come back, I should like to come over to see
you to go over the work as it now stands and perhaps then
I may be able to offer some suggestions about it. For
one thing, it seems to me possible that you have somewhat
over-estimated the amount of work that remains to be done.
What I have in mind is that if the check-up in the next
two weeks shows that the references and quotations are
generally correct it may be quite allowable to let some of
the minor ones go without checking. Of again, it may be
that when the principal references have been checked,
the manuscript can go through for editing and even for
galley proof, leaving you a lee-way of perhaps a couple
of months then to finish up checking minor references.

I think it will be more satisfactory for me to come
to Washington where you have all your work than for you
to attempt to bring it over here. Of course, we want
Miss Carter
-2-
you to come over to Baltimore whenever you can but
when you come we want you to leave your work, both
physically and mentally behind you.

In the meantime, don't let yourself be worried by
any feeling of being rushed for there an old adage about
more haste less speed and after all, there is no present
stampede for priority.

With best regards and hoping that you will take good
care of yourself,
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, W. H. F. whf/f
